title: 103_hr567
content: Increase in limitation on 1-time exclusion of gain from sale of principal residence. The dollar limitation for the 1-time exclusion of gain from the sale of a principal residence is increased to $186,000 ($93,000 for married individuals filing separately) from $125,000 ($62,500). Cost-of-living adjustments will be made for taxable years after 1993 based on the annual cost-of-living adjustment determined under section 1(f)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code. The dollar limitation for the 1-time exclusion of gain from the sale of a principal residence is increased to $186,000 ($93,000 for married individuals filing separately) from $125,000 ($62,500). Any increase determined shall be rounded to the nearest multiple of $1,000. The amendments made by this section shall apply to any sale or exchange after December 31, 1992. SEC. 2. Increase in unified estate and gift tax credits. The estate tax credit under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to replace the specific amount with the "applicable credit amount" based on the tentative tax rate schedule. For decedents after 1993, the applicable credit amount is set at $770,000 with cost-of-living adjustments. For decedents dying after 1993, the estate tax credit amount is increased to $770,000 with cost-of-living adjustments. The unified gift tax credit is also amended to reflect the applicable credit amount under section 2010(c). The amendments made by this section apply to estates of decedents dying and gifts made after December 31, 1992. SEC. 3. REDUCTION IN CAPITAL GAINS TAX FOR INDIVIDUALS. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to add a new section allowing a deduction for capital gains. The Internal Revenue Code allows a deduction for net capital gains for individuals, excluding gains from sales or exchanges of capital assets for estates and trusts. Additionally, the deduction under section 1202 is disallowed for minimum tax purposes. Conforming amendments are made to ensure consistency in the tax code. The Internal Revenue Code makes various amendments to deductions and capital gains, including repealing subsection (h), amending section 62(a) to include a capital gains deduction, and adjusting sections 163(d)(4)(B) and 170(e)(1)(B) for deductions related to gains. Section 172(d)(2) is also amended regarding capital gains and losses for taxpayers. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code includes restrictions on deductions for capital gains and losses for taxpayers other than corporations. Section 172(d)(4)(B) is also amended to include additional references. Section 221 is modified as well. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code includes restrictions on deductions for capital gains and losses for taxpayers other than corporations. Section 221 is modified to include additional cross references. The Internal Revenue Code amendment restricts deductions for capital gains and losses for non-corporate taxpayers. Section 221 is updated with more cross references. Adjustments are made for deductions related to capital assets held for over a year. The amendment restricts deductions for capital gains and losses for non-corporate taxpayers under the Internal Revenue Code. It includes adjustments to various sections such as 643(a) and 691(c), with specific references to section 1202 for deductions related to net capital gain and excess of capital gains over capital losses. The amendment modifies sections 871(a), 904(b)(2), and 904(b)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code, specifically addressing capital gain rate differentials for corporations. The amendment addresses capital gain rate differentials for corporations, specifically related to tax rates imposed by sections 11, 511, or 831(a) and the alternative rate under section 1201(a). The amendment in section 1402(i)(1) of the Code removes exclusions for gains or losses from dealing in section 1256 contracts and eliminates the deduction provided by section 1202 for options and commodities dealers. The table of sections for part I of subchapter P of chapter 1 of the Code is amended by adding a new item. Section 1202 allows for a deduction for capital gains. The amendments will apply to taxable years after the enactment of the Act.
